A.strategy: from a stable-ish pattern (black keys) turning new keys on or off one by one to see how it changed / felt / looked as a whole.
A.expectations_vs_outcome: I couldn't imagine what it would be like from looking at the light pattern but I liked the sound and the correlations. the nature-like patterns and the shift in feel when adding a new colour, then the chaos broke out but managed to regain composure by the end.

B.strategy: try and create a pleasing sound, play with parameters randomly, full > empty / less > more / faster > slower
B.expectations_vs_outcome: I had no idea what it would be like so no expectations aside from faster to slower / more > less light. I had forgotten that compaitble colours made compatible tones which is perhaps why I didn't make a 'pleasing' chord/ sound. I did like the way it looked.

C.strategy: audio focussed, playing with fewer parameters and the scale in search of a more pleasing sound, also the fuller > emptier spectrum
C.expectations_vs_outcome: I enjoyed the looping rhythms both visually and in sound

reflection:
For me, the audio had to be removed completely before I could prioritise the visual - the audio was more important to my overall experience - the avoidance of overwhelm and generation of feelings of pleasure or balance.
Audio only was hardest - perhaps also because I did it first,  but perhaps because I had no other reference point to go by. 
I liked the sense of having control yet also being fully in imperfection and play and surprise.
I don't really understand the audio-visual relationship but already more than I did at the start. 
It's magic!
session_notes_transcription: you could just spend hours and hours; with the visuals turned off you have no idea; cant remember what anything does now; everytime i try to loop the whole thing stops; cant get anything to sound vaguely nice, not doing jazz anymore; dont have a choice but ot make something that doens sound nice; still dont understand what the parameters are doing; lets try turning them all on; quite a relief (playing without headphones on) because you know (just by looking that) it would be cacophonous; liked it when that blue note came in;emergence - imperfection to allow yourself to play is a good excercise regardless of output; nice to do it without sound;
